sentence: Seven acquisitions in 2016 (so far), a Fortune 500 company status, recognition as one of the “Top Ten Companies to Work For,” ranking on the Forbes list of the “World’s Most Innovative Companies” for the sixth consecutive year, and news about “Einstein” - all of this sure makes Salesforce.com, Inc. (CRM) look interesting.
Salesforce.com is a cloud computing company established in 1999, specializing in customer relationship management, or CRM.

The company doesn't have just innovative products but also a whole new philanthropy model, called the 1-1-1 model by which, “it donates 1% of its equity, 1% of its employee time, and 1% of its product to improve communities around the world.” Let’s take a closer look at Salesforce.com.
Salesforce has more than doubled its revenue from $3.05 billion in FY 2013 to $6.67 billion FY 2016.
The company has been spending huge sums on sales and marketing, much more than industry standards as well as towards general and administrative expenses.
It has been consistently investing a decent proportion (15%) of its revenue into research and development.
Overall, these three segments swell the operating expenses for the company.
One crucial part which makes many investors uncomfortable is the fact that Salesforce isn’t profitable and continues to report losses.
During FY 2014, it posted a loss of $262.69 million which it drastically reduced (by 81.94%) during FY 2015 to $47.43 million.
The company had free cash flow of $1.32 billion at the end of FY 2016, growing by 50.35% over the figure reported in FY 2015.

Salesforce is the top CRM vendor accounting for almost 20% of the market share; the top five vendors are Salesforce (19.7%), SAP (10.2%), Oracle (7.8%), Microsoft (4.3%), Adobe (3.6%), which together captures 45% of the total market.
According to a Gartner report, the worldwide customer relationship management (CRM) software totaled $26.3 billion in 2015, up 12.3% vis-à-vis $23.4 billion in 2014.

Further reports suggest that majority (80-85% by 2025, per Gartner report) of all CRM software is going to be cloud based in the years ahead, and this bodes well for companies such as Salesforce which have a high concentration of revenue coming from cloud CRM, against on-premise options.

Salesforce acquired seven companies in 2016, a big number compared to a total of ten acquisitions in the past three years (5 in 2015, 1 in 2014 and 4 in 2013); majority of them belong to machine learning, artificial intelligence and predictive analytics.
In February, Salesforce acquired PredictionIO, an open source machine learning platform which was later donated by Salesforce to the Apache Software Foundation for its ASF incubator program.

This shows Salesforce’s commitment not just towards machine learning but support for open source community as they would get access to the platform “to build and deploy predictive, intelligent apps at scale.”

It was followed by the acquisition of artificial intelligence start-up MetaMind in April, with the intent to bring real AI solutions to Salesforce customers.
As per a forecast by Tractica, the annual worldwide AI revenue will grow from $643.7 million in 2016 to $38.8 billion by 2025.
In May, it was Israel based Implisit – a data intelligence startup was picked by Salesforce to enhance its CRM software.
In June, it entered into an agreement to buy Demandware, a global leader in cloud commerce solutions.
According to a report, the worldwide spending on digital commerce platforms is expected to reach $8.544 billion by 2020, growing at 14% annually.
In July, Salesforce announced the acquisition of Coolan – a data driven, community-based software program.
Next Salesforce announced the acquisition of Quip - which combines content and communication in a whole new way.

With Quip, Salesforce will be better positioned to explore the future of mobile work where it would face competition from companies such as Google and Microsoft (Google Drive and Microsoft Office 365).

In mid-August, Salesforce announced its seventh acquisition – BeyondCore – a business intelligence and analytics firm which will “enhance the AI capabilities of Analytics Cloud,” Marc Benioff’s tweet read.

The future enterprise software will need to be much more advanced, smarter and predictive and these recent bets are a part of the process Salesforce is undertaking to equip itself well enough for the times ahead while it continues to strengthen its core product – CRM software.
Some of Salesforce’s earlier acquisitions have been RelateIQ, Tempo AI, Toopher, Kerensen Consulting, MinHash, and SteelBrick, among others.
The company is set to unveil its new artificial intelligence technology, Salesforce Einstein at Dreamforce in early October, 2016.

Marc Benioff predicts it be a big step forward for the company’s growth; he told Forbes, “If this is not the next big thing, I don’t know what is.”

While much is not known about Einstein, it is expected to amalgamate artificial intelligence into majority of products offered by Salesforce, making them more powerful in terms of insight, understanding and analytical suggestion.
Salesforce’s presents a great combination of sound growth, market leadership and innovative approach.
However, it needs to pull its bottom-line out of red to make investors happier as well generate trust in its futuristic capabilities.
It currently has a market capitalization of $54.21 billion and its shares are up by 2% year-to-date while 1-year return is about 15%.
The author has no position in any stocks mentioned.
Investors should consider the above information not as a de facto recommendation, but as an idea for further consideration.
The views and opinions expressed herein are the views and opinions of the author and do not necessarily reflect those of Nasdaq, Inc.
